Notes: An operculate snail with sessile eyes.
freshwater snail
Glossy.
Glossy.
Ovate-conic. Aperture almost closed by teeth.
Transverse Striae weak. Only 2 teeth.
Typically 5 teeth.
Eight teeth
Cylindrical ovate. Weak striae. Five teeth.
Usually 5\123 sometimes 4\123 teeth.
Six teeth.
Weak striation.
Shell is honey yellow. Mostly with 3 teeth.
Granules or puncta only seen under high magnification. Five teeth.
Transverse striae under magnification.
Narrowly umbilicate (diameter is 6 1/2x umbilicus).
Narrowly umbilicate (contained 9 to 11 times in diameter).
Catinella species have spires almost as long as aperture.
Catinella species have spires almost as long as aperture.
Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.837 as Succinea avara

Notes: Spire is smaller than aperture. Genital aperture noticably swollen.
Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.801 as Succinea ovalis

Notes: Oxyloma have spires smaller than aperture opening. Aperture is narrowly ovate.
Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.785 as Oxyloma retusa

Notes: Oxyloma have spires smaller than aperture. Aperture is narrow.
Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.790 as Oxyloma effusa subeffusa

Notes: Globose to moderately depressed.
Differentiated from A. alterna by orange mucus color.
Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p. 575 as Anguispira alternata fergusoni
Vol. II Part 2 p. 605 as Discus cronkheiti catskillensis

Notes: Widest umbilicus of any Discus (except bryanti).
Very flattened.

Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.600 as Discus cronkheiti

Notes: Spiral striae missing or weak from first 1.5 whorls.

Pilsbry: Vol. II Part 2 p.617 as Discus shimeki

Notes: Spirals only evident under high magnification
First 1 1/2 whorls are smooth\123 then has closely spaced ribs and spiral striae
First whorl irregularly wrinkled. Last 3/4 embryonic whorl spiral striae become more distinct.
Irregularly striate. Sometimes has fine spiral lines. Glossy.
Teeth can be seen through botom of shell. But none in aperture.
Sometimes shell has no visible shell navel (umbilicus) and the apertural whorl shows a slight blunt keel.
Spiral striae start at apex. Weak growth wrinkles.
Ribs are on upper half of whorls.
Ribs start after first 1.5 whorls. Umbilicus 1/3 width of body.
very young shells may have basal lamina
Umbilicus contained 8 times in diameter.
Spiral striae is extremely faint.
Animal is black.
Indented transverse striae-- usually about 28. Umbilicus contained 25 to 30 times in diameter. Spiral striae fine.
Transver striae are indented-- 38 to 45. Can see penultimate whorl in umbilicus. Umbilicus 7 times in diameter.
Transverse striae indented. Spiral striae faint.
Smooth surface. Coppery tint.
Papillae are closely arranged almost in a spiral striae.
coarser microsculpture with grooved ridges
Separated from N. electrina by being smaller\123 its shell is white with greenish tint. Animal dark blue.
Shell transparent with a faint yellow or green tint. Very dark animal.
Growth wrinkles most pronounced at sutures. Gives off a scent of garlic when handled.

Umbilicus 6 times in diameter. Shell clear corneous with a faint amber or yellowish above\123 and whitish around umbilicus. Animal light gray\123 darker above\123 pale sole\123 and brown spots at mantle.
Umbilicus contained 6 times in diameter.
Two to four rows of 4-5 teeth seen in body whorl from the base of shell.
More openly umbilicat than H. miniscula and has a half whorl more. Umbilicus containte 2.5 times in diameter.
Umbilicus about 3 times in diameter. Embryonic whorl smooth\123 then unevenly striate above\123 smooth below. Transverse striae are under magnification\123 and spiral striae are faint.
Shell barely covers animal.
Last whorl has thread-like striae\123 and close impressed spiral lines often punctate in places. Short callus or low tooth in basal margin.
Embryonic 1.5 whorls smooth\123 then finely striate with microscopic spiral lines. Umbilcus 7 times in diameter. Tooth on basocolumellar margin and another on parietal wall.
Parietal tooth turned to thickened basal lp.
The entire profile of this may be wrong. Need more research.
Aperture lip is three-lobed. Parietal tooth is long and somewhat curved.
Umblicus is always only partially covered.
Embryonic whorl has smooth tip\123 then finely striate.
Similar to Mesodon elevatus but umbilicus is always closed while M. elevatus is always at least partially open.
Usually has parietal tooth\123 but may be absent.
Parietal tooth usually present\123 but may be absent.

Usually no parietal tooth\123 but can be present. Embryonic shell with a band of fine striae radiating below the suture\123 elsewhere smooth. Later whorls with sculpture of fine oblique striae and minute \123 crowded\123 spiral lines.
Parietal tooth always present. Embryonic 1.3 whorls have radial striae below suture\123 short at first\123 but later extending half across the whorl.
Papillae are microscopic and form spiral lines towards the end of upper surface of the last whorl.
First half whorl smooth\123 next half whorl closely striate below suture.
Stiff hairs about 0.5mm in length\123 widely spaced\123 cross the lines of growth at nearly a right angle. Width of the mouth is 1mm-- double S. stenotrema.
Periphery sharply angular. Embryonic whorl minutely granulose.
Umbilicus contained about 9 times in diameter. First whorl smooth with a band of short radial striae below suture. Minute papillae around umbilicus. Parietal tooth is long and very curved.
Last whorl has traces of spiral lines below suture. Dense minute papillae at umbilicus below suture. Aperture nearly closed by teeth.

Peripheral end of parietal tooth slants towards or above the upper lip-tooth. Upper lip-tooth is situated lower than T. tridentata making the distance between teeth shorter than distance of either tooth to end of lip. Papillae around umbilicus.
Threatened. Only know to the Cheat River Gorge in West Virginia but could theoretically occur in the bordering southwestern counties of PA. Be on the lookout!
Parietal tooth points below upper lip-tooth. Papillae around umbilicus\123 sometimes above whorl. Umbilicus contained 7 times in diameter.
Parietal tooth points above upper lip-tooth.
Usually without parietal tooth. Sometimes without color bands. Rather glossy. First 1.5 whorls smooth\123 then fine oblique striae with weakly spiral engraved lines in their intervals.
Parietal tooth extends to umbilical callous.
